headline: Travel & Tourism set to Break All Records in 2024
context: Global GDP impact predicted to exceed $11 trillion in 2024
Unprecedented job numbers expected in the sector

annotations.paragraph: New York, U.S.: The World Travel & Tourism Council (WTTC) is projecting a record-breaking year for Travel & Tourism in 2024, with the sector’s global economic contribution set to reach an all-time high of $11.1 trillion.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on the projected economic contribution of the sector.

annotations.paragraph: According to the global tourism body’s 2024 Economic Impact Research (EIR), Travel & Tourism will contribute an additional $770BN over its previous record, stamping its authority as a global economic powerhouse, generating one in every 10 dollars worldwide.
annotations.reason: Offers detailed financial projections and significance of the sector.

annotations.paragraph: As the global sector soars past its pre-pandemic prosperity, WTTC expects 142 countries of 185 analysed will be outperforming previous national records.
annotations.reason: Highlights the expected performance of countries in the sector.

annotations.paragraph: In partnership with Oxford Economic, WTTC’s latest EIR showcases a sector briming with opportunities, underpinning almost 348MN jobs globally. This represents an increase of more than 13.6MN jobs compared to its highest point in 2019.
annotations.reason: Provides job growth data and partnership information.

annotations.paragraph: International visitor spending is expected to come within touching distance of the 2019 peak, to reach $1.89TN, while domestic tourists are forecast to spend more than in any year on record to hit $5.4TN.
annotations.reason: Gives specific figures on expected spending by international and domestic tourists.

annotations.paragraph: A look back on last year
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a vague introduction without specific information.

annotations.paragraph: Despite economic uncertainties and geopolitical shake-ups, the Travel & Tourism sector is thriving. With an economic injection of nearly $10TN, the sector matched its pre-pandemic zenith, flexing its resilience and proving its critical role in the global economy.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant context about the sector's recovery and economic impact.

annotations.paragraph: Representing 9.1% of global GDP at just over $9.9TN in 2023, Travel & Tourism’s financial footprint was the largest it’s been since the golden year of travel in 2019, trailing its peak by a mere 4%.
annotations.reason: Offers specific data on the sector's GDP contribution, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The sector also bolstered its workforce by an additional 27.4MN, propelling the total to nearly 330MN jobs worldwide.
annotations.reason: Provides important information about job growth in the sector.

annotations.paragraph: International spending increased by 33.1% to reach $1.63TN, underscoring a vibrant comeback story for many countries around the world, with domestic spending increasing by more than 18% to reach almost $5TN.
annotations.reason: Gives specific figures on spending increases, relevant to the sector's growth.

annotations.paragraph: 2023 set the stage, demonstrating the unwavering passion for travel, paving the way for a record-breaking year in 2024.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context for the anticipated growth in 2024.

annotations.paragraph: This growth comes despite two of the world’s biggest tourism markets lagging in terms of international visitor spend, with both the U.S. and China seeing a far slower return of international tourist spend.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about challenges in major markets.

annotations.paragraph: Last year in the U.S., international visitor spending remained more than a quarter below the peak of 2019, while China’s visitor spend remained almost 60% down.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives specific data on international visitor spending, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: “This isn’t just about breaking records, we’re no longer talker about a recovery – this is a story of the sector back at its best after a difficult few years, providing a significant economic boost to countries around the world and supporting millions of jobs.
